title: How to Handle Distracted Students During Soroban Practice
description: Practical strategies for keeping unfocused kids engaged during soroban learning.
imageAlt: Child refocusing on soroban with teacher guidance

content.intro: Some kids can't sit still for 5 minutes. Others space out constantly. Here's how to make soroban work even for the most distracted learners.

sections.text: Strategy 1: Match Duration to Attention Span
Don't fight their biology. Work WITH their attention span.
Instead of one 15-minute session, try three 5-minute micro-sessions throughout the day. Works especially well for ADHD kids.

items: Consistent location (brain associates place with focus)

sections.text: Kids with excess energy struggle to focus. Let them run around, do jumping jacks, or dance for 2 minutes BEFORE practice. Burn energy, then sit.
Passive learning = lost focus. Active engagement = focus maintained. Ask questions. Have them explain. Race against the clock. Compete with you.
For highly distracted kids, I use "beat your time" challenges. 10 problems as fast as possible. They're too focused on winning to be distracted.

items: Having a fidget toy in one hand
Emotional upset from earlier in the day

sections.text: Address root causes, not just symptoms.

faq.question: Should I get my child tested for ADHD?
faq.answer: If distraction is severe and persistent across all activities, it's worth talking to a pediatrician. But many kids are simply energetic and grow out of it.

faq.question: What if they literally can't do 5 minutes?
faq.answer: Start with 2 minutes. Build up by 1 minute per week. Progress is progress.

faq.question: Is soroban good for ADHD kids?
faq.answer: Often yes! The hands-on, visual nature can be grounding. Many ADHD kids do better with soroban than traditional math because it's active.

cta.text: SoroKid keeps kids engaged with interactive gameplay and short practice bursts.
